subtopics.title: Introduction to Number Systems
subtopics.content:
Introduction

The number system is the foundation of mathematics. It includes natural numbers, whole numbers, integers, rational numbers, irrational numbers, and real numbers.

subtopics.title: Natural Numbers (N)
subtopics.content:
Natural Numbers

These are the numbers we use for counting objects: 1, 2, 3, 4, …

They start from 1 and go on infinitely.

Example: Counting apples → 1 apple, 2 apples, etc.

subtopics.title: Whole Numbers (W)
subtopics.content:
Whole Numbers

Whole numbers include all natural numbers plus 0.

So, W = {0, 1, 2, 3, …}.

Example: If there are zero chocolates in a box, we still represent it with a number (0).

subtopics.title: Integers (Z)
subtopics.content:
Integers

Integers include all positive and negative whole numbers, along with zero.

Z = {…, –3, –2, –1, 0, 1, 2, 3, …}.

Example: A lift moving 3 floors up (+3) or 2 floors down (–2).

subtopics.title: Rational Numbers (Q)
subtopics.content:
Rational Numbers

Numbers that can be expressed in the form p/q, where p and q are integers and q ≠ 0.

Includes fractions, terminating decimals, and repeating decimals.

Example: 2/3, –4/5, 0.25 (¼).

subtopics.title: Irrational Numbers
subtopics.content:
Irrational Numbers

Numbers that cannot be expressed as p/q.

Their decimal expansion is non-terminating and non-repeating.

Examples: √2, √3, π, e.

subtopics.title: Real Numbers (R)
subtopics.content:
Real Numbers

The set of all rational and irrational numbers combined.

Every point on the number line represents a real number.

subtopics.title: Properties of Real Numbers
subtopics.content:
Properties of Real Numbers

Density Property: Between any two real numbers, there exists another real number.

Decimal Representation:

  • Rational → terminating or repeating decimals.
  • Irrational → non-terminating, non-repeating decimals.

subtopics.title: Laws of Exponents
subtopics.content:
Laws of Exponents

  • a^m × a^n = a^(m+n)
  • a^m / a^n = a^(m-n)
  • (a^m)^n = a^(mn)
  • a^0 = 1 (a ≠ 0)
  • a^(-m) = 1/a^m

questions.question: Which of the following is the smallest set containing 0?
questions.explanation: 0 is included in whole numbers, not natural numbers. Whole numbers = {0, 1, 2, 3, ...}

questions.question: The decimal expansion of a rational number is always:
questions.explanation: Rational numbers can be either terminating (like 1/2 = 0.5) or repeating (like 1/3 = 0.333...)

questions.question: Which of the following is an irrational number?
questions.explanation: √5 cannot be expressed as p/q and has a non-terminating, non-repeating decimal expansion, making it irrational.

questions.question: Every integer is:
questions.explanation: Any integer n can be written as n/1, which fits the definition of a rational number (p/q where q≠0).

questions.question: The value of 2^(-3) is:
questions.explanation: By the negative exponent rule, a^(-m) = 1/a^m. So 2^(-3) = 1/2^3 = 1/8.

questions.question: The square root of 2 is:
questions.explanation: √2 is non-terminating and non-repeating, which makes it an irrational number.

questions.question: Which of the following has a terminating decimal expansion?
questions.explanation: 7/8 = 0.875, which is a terminating decimal. 1/3 = 0.333... and 2/11 = 0.181818... are repeating decimals.

questions.question: Between 1 and 2, how many rational numbers exist?
questions.explanation: Due to the density property of rational numbers, there are infinitely many rational numbers between any two rational numbers.

questions.question: The product of two irrational numbers is always:
questions.explanation: The product can be either. For example, √2 × √2 = 2 (rational), but √2 × √3 = √6 (irrational).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true?
questions.explanation: Real numbers include both rational and irrational numbers, so every rational number is also a real number.
